I saw this movie with four other people who were all similarly unimpressed and I got the feeling that the mood in the movie theatre was generally shared as the credits rolled.I would not recommend this movie.

Sy Parrish (Robin Williams) is the technician at the SavMart photo lab where he has worked for many years. Over time he has gotten to know many of the customers, but none more so than the Yorkin family. But just how far does Sy's obsession run?One Hour Photo is simply a stunning film; it's a tour de force of a movie that is not only a stunning debut movie (80's flick 'Static' not withstanding) from an exciting young director, but also boats a career best performance from Robin Williams.Williams is so convincing as Seymour 'Sy' Parrish that you completely forget that you are watching the man that tortured the movie watching world with the likes of 'Bicentennial Man', 'What Dreams May Come', 'Patch Adams', 'Father's Day', 'Jack', 'Flubber' and 'Mrs. Doubtifre'. But, I digress; it seems vulgar to mention such films in the same breath as this stunning performance. Williams builds on the work he did in Insomnia (which was actually filmed after this film, but you understand what I'm saying, right?) and brings to film history one of the finest portrayals of anonymous danger.Williams Sy is the guy you see every day, but never give more than a passing thought to. But, what if he is giving more than a passing thought to you? What if he has become so obsessed with your family that he starts turning up at your lunch break, or your kid's sports practice? Williams plays Sy perfectly, so ambiguous, so controlled. You're never sure what he's thinking behind those cold, cold eyes. His many voiceovers are delivered with an ice cold matter-of-fact manner that sends a chill down the spine. You're never quite sure what Sy is capable of, Williams never gives anything away and this creates tension from the very first frame. It's tension that continues to build slowly and deliberately throughout the film right up to the final frame. The tension practically drips out of the screen during the scenes where Sy 'bumps' into the various members of the family outside of the SavMart setting, you feel as uncomfortable as the family members, it's impressive stuff. Williams cold ambiguous manner coupled with Romanek's stark visual style leave the viewer unsettled and unsure what to expect next from the film. This certainly no by-the-numbers Hollywood stalker/slasher film, that much is certain.Romanek has teamed up with David Fincher's cinematographer of choice Jeff Cronenweth to produce a visually astounding movie. Although both Fincher and Romenek have a background in music videos, Fincher is a lot flashier than Romanek. Romanek's style is subdued, but stark and barren. The movie is beautifully filmed, with incredible use of light employed, whether it's in the sterile white photolab or the warm home of the Yorkin's. A stunning lighting effect is used in the final moments of the film to ground Sy in one of his earlier voiceovers. It's an incredible moment and one that will live with me for a good while.I look forward to Romaneks next film as after his work here he can now be mentioned in the same breath as the likes of Soderbergh, PT Anderson, Fincher and Nolan as a new hot director to watch out for.
Williams steals this film, but let's not do disservice to the rest of the cast who step up to the plate and give some admirable work. Connie Nielsen is perhaps the best on offer; she works well as the mother of the Yorkin family. I like Michael Vartan in TV show 'Alias' and it's nice to see him in a film, he is given little to do until later in the film, but he handles some difficult scenes well. Dylan Smith has little to do, but be suitably cute as the Yorkin's son.It's always nice to see Gary 'Boss from Hell' Cole and he again plays a boss here. He had better watch out though, or he'll become stereotyped! Also, apparently there is life after ER as Eriq La Salle pops up later in the film and has some impressive scenes with Williams.The supporting players however, are just the lettuce at the side of the cheeseburger that is Robin Williams. I cannot stress how good he is here; it's easily his best work to date, surpassing the likes of 'The World According To Garp', 'Good Will Hunting', 'The Fisher King', 'Dead Poet's Society' and the recent 'Insomnia'. This is an Oscar worthy performance, but I fear that the Academy might shirk at the films dark subject matter and ambiguous nature. The Academy likes easy films, which One Hour Photo is certainly not.In-fact One Hour Photo is a cold, dark, ambiguous film that leaves the viewer unsure of its direction for the entire running time. It asks questions of the viewer constantly and leaves itself burned into the viewers conscience long after the end titles have rolled and the lights have came up.9/10 for One Hour Photo.

I finally got around to renting this DVD. It was worth the wait. The film at first seems to be a "Psycho" remake, but Robin Williams and the director Mark Romanek have crafted a truly beautiful parable of our isolated modern age. "Sy" (Seymour- SEE MORE?) is the anti-hero in this film. Perhaps hero is too strong a term, but in a world of directionless yuppie drones who choose to ignore life, he becomes a sort of existential man of action. Is he creepy and disturbed? Yes. But so are all of the blandly "normal" characters in the film. ( The young son is an exception to this rule). Most of the TV clips you may have seen really don't reveal the depth of characterization Williiams and Romanek give to Sy. In less capable hands this could have been a horrible film, but all of the characters seem all too human, and well drawn. As a former One Hour Photo employee myself, I can say that they got the working environment 100% on target. There is some very subtle and clever cinematography. Watch for how the tone of color changes to set the mood, to warm yellows when Sy interacts with people, and cold blue-white when he is alone. Even though this is a cinema buff's film, the plot turns and suspense are top notch and will keep you watching until the end; it will also keep you thinking for a good while afterwards.

Review title: Bad. VERY bad. Don't waste your time...
Review_body: The film looked very interesting in the first hour. Then, it started to decline, really fast. The end of the file is VERY VERY DISAPPOINTING. After watching the whole film, I'm sorry I've wasted those 90 minutes. Go read a book or something instead...

Before I begin, I should mention that I have been an Alfred Hitchcock fan since the age of five, and for me to even compare any film made in the last twenty years to even the worst Hitchcock film is totally unheard of.  I view hitchcock as most film buffs view Orson Welles.  With that being said, I left the movie theater after viewing One Hour Photo utterly spellbound. The same uneasy (not necessarily nervous) feeling that one experiences during a film like Notorious or North By Northwest can be experienced here.  The audience isn't scared of Williams' character, they're uncomfortable around him, which is just how the other characters in the film view him.  The other great element of the film is that it is easy to follow.  While the trend in the mystery / thriller genre of today is to confuse and disorientate the audience as a means of creating tension, the director takes down a straight road that has several bumps along the way, which provides the same tension without all the confusion (See this film, then watch either Memento or Mulholland Drive).  I can go on and on, but I will leave you with the this as a close to this review.  This is the first film in some years that I left the movie theater feeling that I really got my money's worth ($8.00 per ticket).

When I went to see this movie I really had no expectation. Some said it was boring, some said it lacks of action. I believe that a movie like this one does not need to be action packed. With something as simple as the life of a guy who works at Sav-Mart (a shop exactly like Wal-Mart), they created a thriller atmosphere. A maniac-compulsive man, a truly professional in both his job and hobby: photo. This movie proove that even the life of the quite everyday guy could do an incredible movie, wich of course have incredible actors.

Review title: Robin Williams is back in action
Review_body:
This can be said very short. Robin Williams is still one of the greatest actors we have at this time. This movie is great. I have heard some refer it to the works of Hitchcock, which I only can agree. But it wouldn't have been this great without the outstanding performence of Robin Williams.
It is not a scary movie, but it certainly is a creepy movie, that slowly goes under your skin and stays there.All in all, this is a great thriller.

One Hour Photo was possibly one of the most interesting movies I've watched. I don't know exactly what it is, but this movie was just really good. Before this movie, I never considered the fact that the people at a one hour photo place looked through our lives, saw the places we've been, and the people we've encountered. To me, the thought doesn't make the workers creepy, but their jobs in general feel quite invasive. This film also made me realize that we, as a society, can be very blind to those who we take for granted. For example, Sy the photo guy is clearly obsessed with Nina and her family, yet Nina just sees it as a passion for what he does. She just doesn't notice all the little things Sy does for her. Instead, she simply takes it as quality customer service. Is she naïve, blind, or just uncaring towards this meek, insignificant photo guy? Robin Williams does a fantastic job portraying the inner psyche of a scared (and creepily meticulous) young boy who is trapped inside an awkward adult.

When recently I was watching the Joker somehow reminded me for this one. Great representation of what loneliness and the everyday life routine can do with person's mind. Such strong feelings combined with Robbie Williams great acting can never get to old to re-watch.

Mark Romanek is not only a good director, it's even a great photographer. The main scenes of the movie are constructed like if they were thought for photographic shots. It's not a Tarantino's movie where the characters speaks too much for expressing their inner feelings, in this movie the set speaks for the characters: Emblematic is the scene where Sy is lied down on the bed of the mall alone. He is Alone in a place full of people, how is it possible? It happens because malls are fake places where fake people smile everyday and fake mothers and fathers walk quietly thinking to be happy. Sy is a victim of a commercial society that privileges the image to the communication of the emotions. Sy is alone, he hasn't friends, parents or someone who loves him, he has been spending his time watching the life of the others in the pictures he prints. He is a shlemiel who desires to be happy and loved. His faith in the image pushes him to change its good-natured aspect in cynical but its weapon is not the gun but the camera. Only in this way he thinks to be able to convert the running values and to see recognized its human superiority on the others. But he has forgotten an important thing: In a fake society made by fake people where the simple and pure men are defeated even imagine can be fake!! He is only the reproduction of a fake reality and it is not enough to allow him to conquer the life of his dreams. He was a victim and now he is a monster.

*SPOILERS*I expected more from this film.  The premise of a photo-lab techincian developing an unhealthy relationship with his customers was an intriguing one.  However, this movie was dull, poorly-acted, and boring.  There was not enough background on any of the characters to create sympathy, and Williams' character's behavior was not explained until an astoundingly trite (and insufficient) scene at the end of the film. This left me feeling annoyed and wondering why in the world he was doing all of these things, and why I was expected to care.Overall, the performances were stilted and the dialogue trite.  The supposedly "shocking" hotel scene was incredibly lame--I actually laughed as I was watching it.  I couldn't believe what I was seeing, and not because it was "shocking" and confrontational, but because it was so stupid and unnecessary.  The grimaces of "shame" and "fear" on the characters' faces were ridiculous, and Williams' overacting was embarrassing.This is a bad, bad movie.  I just watched it and I've already forgotten most of what I saw. The symbolism was overdone...the entire thing just seemed so contrived. In fact, this movie was so bland that I came away from it with the vague feeling that I'd seen it before.  Unoriginal, boring, bland, bad.Ultimately, this one gets a 3/10 from me.  Not worth the effort.

Review title: Someone Watched "The Shining" Too Many Times
Review_body: "One Hour Photo" is a great thriller that unabashedly borrows tactics from Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining": the tracking shots, the "linear" cinematography, the Black guy who can't wait to help the white family, a sensitive child character, and the overall weirdness. I read in the IMDb trivia that Jack Nicholson was originally asked to play the role of "Sy", but that would have made this film into too obvious of a "Shining" rip-off. Robin Williams' convincing and compassionate acting as "Sy" bent the film in a different direction. He is much more subtle than Nicholson, who we can imagine as being constantly at the boiling point in many of his other roles. Williams delivers a feminized performance, where even his victims, being held at knifepoint can't seem to be dominated by his weak persona. This movie is full of thriller genre clichés, yet is still very engaging and likable.

Review title: literate and spare script and great lead add up to excellent film
Review_body: In this movie, the first one where I've seen Robin Williams in a serious lead role, he dominates the screen with his total immersion into his character. To watch him in pain hurts the viewer. The theater where I went to see this movie with a friend was completely silent, not a sound--everyone was fully drawn into this film and connected to it. Of course, it's easier to connect to a character who has the opportunity to commit murder but does not, seeking to punish the transgressor, but this doesn't take anything away from Williams--he's simply great, possibly Oscar worthy. I was slightly disturbed by the fact that the boy ran to his father at the end, although he knew of the father's infidelity. Other than that, this is easily one of the best films I've seen this year.

Script would have been more appropriate for an hour of episodic network TV.  Took itself way too seriously.  Characters seldom seem "real"....if you're fired, you're out.  Too many shots were standard "music video" composition.  Predictable.  Probably used that crappy "I'll help write your script" software.

Review title: This Is Not a Music Video, Mr. Romanek
Review_body: The premise of One Hour Photo is original, intriguing, and creepy.  In fact, that premise and the reports of Robin Williams's performance pulled me into the theater to see this movie.  Unfortunately, the delicately creepy premise gets bogged down by the overblown production and the story never really gets off the ground (and ends up suffering from a couple of  huge lapses of logic).  From the beginning of the story's chronology, the movie keeps flashing neon signs that scream "creepy movie, creepy movie," such as the unnecessary and annoying bursts of suspenseful music during early expository scenes that are neither creepy nor suspenseful.  It is as though the director is afraid the audience won't get it, or worse, can't pay attention to the movie long enough to come to that conclusion on their own.  There is nothing subtle here, except perhaps the drowning of a promising storyline in a lot of fluff.

I went with my dad to see this out of the lack of good movies going around right now. And I'm happy I did. One Hour Photo is one of the most amazing films I have ever seen."One Hour Photo" focuses on a man named Seymour "Sy" Parrish who works at the photo development area in Savmart. He seems normal, if a little monotone. He definately loves his work. But theres something more. Hes fixated on The Yorkins, a family he has been developing pictures for. In secret, he makes extra prints of the pictures they want developed and takes them for his own, quietly adopting the family as his own. Then one day, everything changes.I loved this movie. Pure and simple. But, I wouldnt have loved it as much if Robin Williams wasnt in it. He makes Seymour come alive and does a hell of a job doing it. After this and "Insomnia", if he doesnt get an Oscar nomination, Im gonna be really surprised. See One Hour Photo ASAP!

Pretty cool flick.  I really enjoyed how the film was seen through Robin Williams' eyes, as opposed to the family's eyes (which the normal Hollywood film would do).  A few tiny holes that bothered me but overall the film creeped me out and makes me think twice about my "photo guy."

The entire time I watched this movie, I felt as though I were looking at an endless series of snapshots. Everything was too perfect and clean, and the colours too crisp and pure, the store too vast and white and gleaming... but not enough to make the surreality of the setting obscure the story. Everything's just this side of reality--just like when, for example, you see the photos of someone that they want to show you, the best ones. None of the ones where their hair is messed-up, their expression silly, their rear shot at an unflattering angle can be found--there's nary a single shot in this masterpiece out of place. As Sy's voice-over says, if you look through a person's photo albums, you might come away with the impression that nothing bad ever happens to them. In addition to including the key colours of photo development and emphasizing Sy's sterile, lonely identity with the whites, beiges and taupes of his environments, we are placed artistically in a world that can only be described as picture-perfect.I could go on about the cinematography, but that's not all I want to rave about. Robin Williams' performance in Insomnia was like a dress rehearsal for this film--as Sy, he gives us even more of a subtle, spare view into an unstable character's world. With each troubled role he takes on, he performs better and better. True aficionados of character acting will not at all be disappointed by this film... and yes, it sounds strange to me, too, to place Robin Williams in that esteemed acting category. He lives up to the praise he has garnered for this movie, and then some.**SPOILERS BELOW**I've read criticisms of the tensions between Mr. and Mrs. Yorkin--they fight over money, but she spends all her time at the discount store, Savmart. I feel that those who espouse this notion are missing some serious subtleties in the Yorkins' relationship--she feels that he has emotionally distanced himself from the family, and he seems to be expressing misplaced frustration with himself and the situation when he argues with her over her spending. Multiple instances in the movie bear out both complaints--we find he is having an affair, and we discover that Mrs. Yorkin has 'some serious shopping to do' during the day at the mall, and is consistently dressed and coiffed like a model, somewhat out of the norm for your average Savmart customer. It's a very realistic fight between a husband and wife about... nothing that they're actually voicing at all.As to whether or not the nude, posed photos were actually ever taken... well, I, for one, am satisfied to be left without that question being definitively answered. Does it matter? Mr. Yorkin and Maya were both duly humiliated, which was part of the purpose of the exercise. Perhaps it's better if he didn't, if he took pictures of random objects in their room, in his own--it would make us even slightly more sympathetic to Sy. But regardless, the ending makes it fairly clear that whatever the reality of it, Sy was acting against the two of them with, as a previous reviewer so eloquently put it, the worst punishment in his world.It's a picture... act like you're enjoying it. Act like you're having fun. And at the end of it, you're left feeling guilty and dirty and ashamed and angry... somewhat like the way the movie lets you feel at the end. I can't tell you how much I enjoy movies that really live up to Traffic's tagline--"No one comes away clean." Requiem for a Dream was like that, Traffic itself is like that, and One Hour Photo is certainly like that. I think it's a good thing, having been a retail lackey, to have some people realize what it is like to be looked through, to be looked over. And likewise, it's a good thing for others to realize that beautiful people in perfect homes assure their children and themselves that everyone's fine, they have girlfriends and mommies and daddies who love them. Both sets of people could benefit from a viewing of this film, but no one's going to come away with a good and light-hearted feeling when the credits begin to roll.I respect that, in a film.

Review title: Original, well crafted, and well acted
Review_body: The first order of business is to declare that Robin Williams' performance is superb. As far as I'm concerned, this is Williams' best work to date. The second order of business is to point out what initially disturbed me as I was viewing the film for the first time. I felt that the pacing in the beginning was rather slow. But after thinking about it and discussing it with another viewer, I have come to the conclusion that the pacing cleverly supports the main character's persona and reinforces (emphasizes) that character's predicament in life. So the pacing (though at first disturbing) works very well.The cinematography in a number of silent scenes is carefully planned and deliberately symbolic (lots of echoings of photography). In some talking scenes there are "photography" metaphors and historical expositions. Though interesting, these scenes are sometimes slightly intrusive. But overall, I think they help support the careful character development so central to the plot.The script is well written and carries the plot exquisitely to its "terrifying" conclusion. And as it turns out, the reason that the conclusion is so terrifying (Williams' superb acting is a given, of course) is because the pacing, the cinematography, and the metaphors distract the viewer (derail, so to speak) just enough to allow the ending to erupt with such unexpected elegance that the viewer is stunned by the final "meaning" -- the truth being told by this fascinating tale. The "truth," as it turns, out is pretty terrifying.

This is a truely special film that hasn't got its proper recognition. People just don't get it...This movie is about REAL life, REAL people, and REAL problems...Hollywood has had a bad habbit of sugar coating reality.  All movies have happy endings??? The good guy always win???  Everyone is beautiful???Give me a break.  Hollywood has the tendency of making the bad BAD and the good GOOD.  I think most people are somewhere in the middle. I believe that everyone has a dark side and a good side.  We're always so quick to judge, label, and forget about people.A little advice to people in general, never forget anyone.Powerful film, excellent score (soundtrack).  I recommend this film to all those mature enough to pay attention.

The premise of a photo developer becoming emotionally attached to a family through a lifetime of photos is an interesting one, and nicely played out. There is a lot of well thought out moments, albeit fairly obvious - the stark contrast between Sy's bland off-white and light grey world to that of the family which surrounds its moments in colour as an example.  Nothing overly spectacular here, but not all to familiar either, which is refreshing in today's suspense films.  If I had any main criticisms, it is I wish the producers would trust the audience a little more with their own conclusions. We recognise that Sy is nearing the insanity of dillusion, we don't need it spelled out to us in the last shot.  Get rid of the bookends, and the strength of the film increases.

This film is quite understated all the way through. Robin William's acting ability coupled with the cinematography tells a very tense and emotive story which goes above and beyond what is played out on the screen. I felt drawn in to his character and world.Having said this, there was the odd moment where it all felt a little clichéd but they were few and far between.As with all good films, it has its own special personality, heightened by supermarket colours and camera angles, and an interesting concept at it's base.Worth watching in my opinion.

I didn't see this at the movies, I am not a fan of Robin Williams and the trailers didn't appeal, now I regret that. Caught it on TV and was immediately involved.Sadly one reason I was so engaged is i related to the isolation of Sy. The loneliness of people with no family is something few understand.Some of the scenes really capture life of the unconnected. No-one to buy a present for or spend Christmas with, just work, home, work, home ........Of course Sy takes it much farther but hey it's a movie.If you missed this first time around get the DVD but be prepared for a disturbing time.

Review title: The best character portrait since Taxi Driver.
Review_body: Robin Williams gives a very good, albeit surprisingly scary performance here. He plays Sy, a very lonely and psychologically damaged man who works as a photo developer at a local chain store, he becomes completely obsessed with what he perceives as the "perfect family." Visually, it is simplistic but also striking, there is a hint of hyper-realism in the general look of the film. Robin Williams can give a very good dramatic performance when he is given a good script, but in this film he goes to a completely different level. He literally transforms into Sy, and the result is a weak, although dangerous character who we genuinely feel sorry for.I am not sure if anyone has made this comparison before me, but when I watch this film, it reminds me a little bit of Taxi Driver, both Travis and Sy are lonely, their motivations are completely different of course, but both these films are essentially character portraits that deal with loneliness. The supporting cast give reasonably good performances but Williams truly carries the movie.In closing, this film is far from being the best of all time, but it is a great film nonetheless and I recommend it to people who liked Taxi Driver.

This film was utter toss. To expand on that for those not familiar with the term, it was undoubtedly similar to a heterosexual male getting a sudden and unwanted splash of non identifiable male semen on his lower lip. Not pleasant at all. After seeing some of the reviews which use terms like ' genuinely scary' or 'Williams at his best' I can only conclude that we need more hospital beds. And really really good psychiatrists. To make the ultimate statement, I'd rather watch an N'Sync on tour documentary. Nuff said.

One Hour Photo highlights Robin Williams in what is certainly one of the most demanding and chilling roles of his career, and he delivers on every level.  Williams plays Seymour, a lonley film developer at a convenience store one hour photo center, who develops a truly unique relationship with some of his customers.  In an effort to escape the void in his life, Seymour "adopts" these individuals and engrosses himself in their life through the pictures they bring in.  Williams does an outstanding job in this role by playing a character that you can certainly sympathize with to a point, but whose obsession takes him to edges of sanity and beyond.This is the first film I have seen by director Mark Romanek, however he creates the perfect atmosphere through the eerie lighting in Seymour's home, and the occasional peek into his demented thoughts.  Needless to say I will certainly be looking forward to Romanek's next film.  To avoid giving away too much of the film, I will not disclose any details about the climax, or the surprise ending; however I tell you that this movie will not leave you disappointed

ONE HOUR PHOTO September 19, 2002 Sy Parrish: Robin Williams Nina Yorkin: Connie Nielsen Will Yorkin: Michael Vartan Bill Owens: Gary Cole Jake Yorkin: Dylan Smith Det. Van Der Zee: Eriq LaSalle Maya Burson: Erin Daniels Fox Searchlight Pictures presents a film written and directed by Mark Romanek. Running time: 98 minutes. Rated R (for sexual content and language).*** Warning: Some Spoilers ***'One-Hour Photo' is a scary movie.  No, it's not your typical scary movie that we are accustomed to seeing on the big screen.  It's scary because the character that we see on film is not so different than most of us. However, he's not quite right . just a little off, so to speak.  He's like a car we drive which has a cracked windshield.  The car still runs fine, but it's not the same, and the vision of the world we see through that glass . is just a bit warped at times.  Robin Williams plays that character, and his name is Sy Parrish.Sy Parrish has worked in the photo shop at the local SavMart, which is your typical discount store.  He loves his job and takes pride in developing the pictures for SavMart's customers. They are not just SavMart's customers . they are HIS customers.One particular customer is a family by the name of Yorkin.  Sy pays particular attention to this family, for he keeps a set of prints of them just for himself.  He imagines himself being a part of that family.  To him, he is `Uncle' Sy.  Sy doesn't appear to have any family or friends of his own . so he pretends to have a life that is more meaningful . more significant.  To most people, he is just another insignificant person we see in our daily lives.  Sy is someone that wants to be accepted and more importantly . loved.  He lives in a fantasy world.  Why is he this way? What has made him a little more 'cracked' than the rest of us?  We don't really have time to think about that as we watch this movie.  And, come to think of it, we don't take the time to think about people like Sy in our own lives either.This movie, superbly directed by Mark Romanek, utilizes the camera in ways that I've not seen before in a motion picture.  In other words, although this is a `motion' picture, the director lets us take a `snapshot' of the world much how our own mind takes in the series of events we see every day.Robin Williams, in perhaps his best role on screen, is not playing his typical role.  Normally, we either see him as a bigger than life character or the typical `Clown'.  In this movie, he is neither of these things. He is a lonely man, a man without a sense of purpose, at least not in the real world.  He is not very funny, but in fact, quite sad.  And, there is nothing more melancholy and gloomy than that of a sad clown.I highly recommend this movie and give it a score of 8.5 on a scale of 1 to 10.David Hardin

Review title: Think about where you develop your pictures...
Review_body: This movie proved to be a vision for the eyes. It is very visual in how colors represent ideas. Robin Williams also was wonderful. When you watch this movie, you forget it is Robin Williams... and that is proof of a great actor. I highly recommend this film. It is a great art flick with a really strong and interesting plot.

Before I actually sat down to watch this movie I was expecting a Silence Of The Lambs type thriller.  What I got sadly was a great actor giving a fine performance in a weak script.Yes it had originality in parts but basically the ending sucked.I'd buy the soundtrack though!!!6/10

I loved this movie.  Romanek pays attention to the minute details often overlooked by most directors through the use of natural lighting, exceptional cinemaphotography that gives you a moment to take in the scenery and a soundtrack that doesn't force the viewer to keep fiddling with the volume.  At 90 minutes in length, there is no pointless filler doesn't bore you and irrelevant side plots to push it to the 2-hour mark.  It's a movie you can sit back and enjoy without feeling distracted by ridiculous special effects, jittery camera work or a disjointed plot.  It has a peaceful, deep and thoughtful feel to the narration and dialog that is enhanced and complimented by the soundtrack.  You can identify with the characters because they're not some Hollywood fantasy - but real and identifiable everyday people who react as you would expect everyday people to react.Robin Williams has proven that he's a versatile actor.  I've always liked his characters in comedies (i.e., Mork and Mindy, The Birdcage and Death to Smoochy) - however he really shines in more dramatic roles (Moscow on the Hudson and Awakenings).  His character Sy in One Hour Photo takes him to the next level, but he's not the center of attraction.  This is a good thing. Romanek gives the movie a sense of balance by giving characters depth and dimension.  He makes sure that the perfect family that is the focus of Sy's obsession has problems just like everyone else in spite of their picture perfect affluent lifestyle.  We see that while Sy succeeds at work with a warm, friendly disposition - his personal life is cold and lonely with his surroundings at home the same impersonal and sterile environment at work. Sy's character fits perfectly.Another bright spot in One Hour Photo was Dylan Smith, who played the son of the family that Sy is obsessed with.  He's a natural actor who has the ability to play natural characters - an average kid who does a splendid job of acting as an average kid.  Romanek doesn't insult the viewer by subjecting us to the stereotypical, annoying, mouthy, whiny, know-it-all kid with the bowl haircut that has ruined movie after movie.
If I could change something - I would cast someone other than Gary Cole to play Sy's boss.  Maybe it's the MST3K fan inside me saying this, but after seeing Office Space many times, I kept waiting for him to reincarnate the role of Bill Lumbergh in even the most subtle way, mmmm-kay?.  Romanek knew how not to cross the fine line that separated Cole's role as the sadistic boss in Office Space from boss in One Hour Photo.I give this movie a 9.5 out of 10.

Review title: one of robin williams' best performances
Review_body: I was personally anticipating the release of this film ever since I heard of it. Robin Williams gives what I think is definately one of his best roles, as he totally takes on the role of Sy the photo guy. All in all, a very dark film.

Review title: Decent Stalker Movie Where Williams Shines
Review_body: I was going through the OnDemand movie listings one night, looking for a movie to watch. Under the "Deranged Thrillers" section, I found "One Hour Photo." I saw Robin Williams as the lead, and immediately I was drawn to watch the movie. After having watched it, I found it to be a decent stalker movie, saved by the acting of Robin Williams.Robin Williams is truly one of the most underrated all-around actors in Hollywood. He always brings intensity and passion to his roles, as evidenced in _Good Will Hunting (1997)_, _Dead Poets Society (1989)_, and even _Insomnia (2002/I)_. As in those, in _One Hour Photo (2002)_, he saves the movie with his intense demeanor, making his character seem more realistic, and much more creepy. The supporting role players weren't bad, but I feel without Robin Williams, this movie would not have the same feel. I would recommend this movie to anybody who enjoy thrillers with the bonus of a great character actor (Robin Williams) playing the deranged lead.Overall, I found it to be a decent thriller, but I give Robin William's performance an A+.7/10

It's been often said that a great painting can be judged just as much by the use of space surrounding the central subject as the subject itself. The same analogy can adjusted for cinema. Often it is the judicious use of silence that can carry as much of an impact in a movie as the dialog. "One Hour Photo" is such a film. Wearing two hats, that of writer and director, Mark Romanek has enough confidence in the power of his screen play to allow the principle editor (Jeffrey Ford) to set a languid pace to the film and utilize long stretches without chatter. This pace does not hinder the underlying creepiness of the film, on the contrary, the tension packs as slowly and surely as nitrogen in the tissues of a deep sea diver. The central character of the film is Cy Parrish "Cy, the Camera Guy!" played with consummate skill by Robin Williams. Parrish is a film developer that works in a one hour photo within a store that could be any Target or Wal-Mart. Having no life of his own and living day to day through the snap shots taken by others, he becomes enamored, and later, obsessed with a neighborhood family who's only contact with him are the photos that they drop off for development. A word here about Mr. Williams. I have never really considered him a good actor. He's played a multitude of roles and in each one you can see small bits of the Robin Williams "Shtick" peaking out from under the costume.(Another great example would be Chris Walken. I could watch him read a phone book, but have you ever seen him in a role where you didn't find yourself saying "Heh, heh.... Christopher Walken... Cool!"?). This movie changed all that. Rarely have I ever seen an actor submerge so completely his public mannerisms and persona. Robin Williams *was* Cy Parrish, the embodiment of the potential evil that can lurk under even the most banal of exteriors. Kudos are also due to Connie Nielson and Michael Vartan, who play the "twenty something" couple with son that becomes the unknowing object of Cy Parrish's obsession, as well as to Darrell Hall, the supervising music editor. Recommended, 8 out of 10 Bear Claws.

Review title: Beautifully shot, but I'm still trying to understand it
Review_body: Beautifully shot, with beautiful sound. However, strange as it may sound, I'm still not exactly sure I understand what this movie was about, what it was trying to say, or even necessarily what parts of it were real and what parts only occurred in the protagonist's head.I can see many different interpretations for the entire movie, and especially the final scene. Sy the photo guy was definitely more than a little touched in the head, but was he evil? I honestly don't know.

This movie was pretty dark.  I would definitely recommend it, but it is not for everyone.You really get to caring for this guy and you are constantly wondering what the heck he's doing.  Its a great movie, I was glued to my seat even though there was not much action, yet it is riveting.

This film was very good and a lot better than i thought it was going to be.  The Media practically murdered this movie and said all these bad things about it.  When i went to see it, it was great.  It was possibly one of the best movies i have seen in my entire life. From the suspense to the powerful and creepy quotes, One Hour Photo, made one of my top 10.

This movie was very freaky!! Robin Williams plays an excellent pyscho individual.  The moral of the story is that two wrongs do not make something right.  Recommend that you hide all cameras before sleeping :)

Review title: Not exactly what I was thinking
Review_body:
Not exactly what I was thinking when I first began to watch this film. Robin Williams has always played funny man roles in his films. But not this one. It will surprise you and it will amaze you.
Even in the film Insomnia his role was totally unexpected,but you will appreciate.

Review title: A Film For Students of Film
Review_body: This Movie has great acting, great directing, and strikingly beautiful cinematography. I would love to hear what film was used and how much lighting they used. The story is a little shocking and graphic which is a problem for some people, but for me i really liked this movie. It is a modern tale of obsession. It really gives incite into a lonely obsessive persons mind. Robin Williams is great like usual and he continues to expand his resume in this movie. This one will keep you guessing until the very end and will leave you in a cold sweat and a hanging jaw. Go see it if you don't mind movies having a little sexual content in them. I really would not let the kids see this film. It goes over the line several times, but that is life. That is the world we live in. After watching this movie i feel like the main character could be any photo lab expert.

Robin Williams does a decent acting job and its finally a serious role instead of another comedy. I hope he sticks to the more serious roles now since he seems to be a pretty good actor. I thought the film was alright but, it takes itself way to serious and you can tell what is going to happen before the end of the movie rolls around. I briefly worked at a quick develop photo shop myself, inside a mall, and this film does that type of work, no justice. You are constantly rushing film to get developed and being harassed by customers who think all their shots look like professional photographers pictures and if something happens to be wrong then You had to be the one who messed up there pictures. You have No time to be flicking through people's pictures, like you would care to anyways, most of them are rude and sassy to you. It was a headache the whole time I was working there. That said, What type of person wants to go chasing after the inconsiderate, weekend wannabe photographers anyways, get a life Mr Williams!

Review title: I don't understand the high rating on this film.
Review_body: I don't understand the high rating members of this site gave to this film. After reading a number of the reviews, lauding this film as one akin to some of Hitchcock's finest, I purchased the DVD, got some takeout food and settled down with anticipation to enjoy this movie.  I kept waiting for things to improve and stuck it out all the way to the end, at which time I felt great disappointment and shame at having been bilked out of the $19.95 plus tax that I spent on the DVD.  Except for the fact that Robin Williams convinced me that his character was a disturbed weirdo, there was never anything in the movie that got me nervous or excited.  The thing just dragged through one boring scene after another, until the end finally arrived.  Fortunately, I bought The Four Feathers the same day and was able to salvage the evening.

Review title: A plodding example of Hollywood arrogance.
Review_body: A movie that proves you can fool most of the people most of the time. The movie is a plodding example of what Hollywood can con people into wasting ten or twelve dollars of their money.  Although Williams performance as a stand alone feature can be lauded, the movie itself has all of the suspense of a McDonalds commercial and the pace of a turtle.  Next to this movie, 'Traffic' looks like a masterpiece.

Review title: A Wonderful, Challenging, Inspired Piece Of Cinema
Review_body: Review Breakdown:Performances: 5 StarsStoryline: 4 StarsMusic: 5 StarsCinematography: 5 Stars Dialogue, Script, And Actions: 5 StarsTilt: 5 StarsGenre: Thriller (Psychological) Production: IndependentRobin Williams stars as Sy Parrish in this truly unique film revolving around a socially poor photo-lab technician. Watch as Sy pretends to be a part of a family which he has barely met, and simply develops pictures for.Williams's performance, in addition to a smattering of terrific actors, working on a subtle and powerful script make this one of those rare films which you simply can't stop watching. As Sy's dellusions begin to come to fruition later in the film, the audience is granted a unique perspective which allows them to make their own moral judgements about the themes of preciousness and fortune the film argues, in addition to questioning Sy's reactions to them.SEE THIS FILM IF:You like a great storyYou can handle a challenging and complex narrativeYou love darker plotsYou're a fan of independent cinemaAVOID THIS FILM IF:You love big-budget blockbusters and nothing elseYou hated "Crash" (2005)You like films to be fun-filled and entertaining onlyI think most people would love this film - its complex themes and narratives are delivered in a simple, easy to follow way, equipping you to come to your own reactions to this, brilliant, film.VOTE: 10/10 (Truly Fantastic)

Sorry, but this one didn't make it for me.  Robin Williams provides a compelling performance and is oddly peculiar (redundant for sure).  His effort does not warrant the time for the movie.  The movie tried to frighten us -- but didn't reach the level of Pacific Heights, where Michael Keaton was the neighbor from hell. Sometimes good people make bad movies.

This "psychological thriller" could have been much better but it lacked a victim we could like and a bad guy we could hate. I guess the ordinariness was intentional but it bore no resemblance to the real world. There was no grime and the cops were kind and considerate. A threat squad? Give me a break! Then there was Robin Williams' performance. It was so cold and creepy I couldn't help but wonder if he had confused his character in Insomnia with this one. Worse was that this performance was just as wooden. But then, this production was wooden and bland as it plodded along its carefully measured path -- weird, bleeding eyeball scene excepted -- to its flat conclusion. As for the self-righteousness moralising? I just wanted to puke -- I wanted a thriller and got heavy-handed propaganda instead. In all, it was a very disappointing 96 minutes.

What you see in the preview sums up the entire movie, the build up is slow and the ending is anticlimactic. Movie has a good idea behind it but it falls short of what it could have been. I expected so much more after all the critic raves. The acting was good, and it was a good story just had to much lack of. The people sitting behind us said it was a waste of money for the ticket, I do believe the movie was an "O.K" movie and would say RENT the movie on video/dvd... save the theater for something far better.

While I enjoyed this movie (despite it's slow pace), the main character, Sey the Photo Guy (Robin Williams), was underdeveloped.  His actions were not explained and the writer/director never brought his audience close enough to Sey's mindset for us to really understand him.  With more depth and history, the movie would have held a lot more interest and the audience would have left feeling a little more satisfied.

Spoiler! Just wanted to comment on how contrived it seemed that Sy found the photos of Yorkin and Mara at that particular dramatic juncture of the movie(his anger and desperation at their peak).A bit too ripe for my tastes(although it was nice to see Williams do something understated without having to be shot with an elephant tranquilizer between takes-mind you,I haven't seen the special features yet) A.O.

Review title: How anyone can like this movie is beyond me!!
Review_body: I am a huge Robin Williams fan and think he did an excellent job in this movie as well as the other actors, but it is way too slow and nothing really grabs you until the movie is almost over. Too slow for this movie fan!!

One Hour Photo provided me with a mixture of extreme sadness and pure delight. The main character, who`s a real "peeping tom", is played with such sincerity by Robin Williams who seems to have gotten the hang of playing the "bad guy" (last seen in Insomnia).In style and theme it`s easy to compare this flick with films like Magnolia and American Beauty, by which all of them portrays the crucial and life-changing moments which happens to the protagonist. I wouldn`t complain if OHP won an Oscar for best film, but unfortunately the statuette will probably go to some extravagant story with no references to most peoples personal life (ala Gangs of New York)instead of this wonderful treasure. Bye

Review title: The best film I've seen in the past 8 months.
Review_body: One Hour Photo is a must-see movie.  Robin Williams does an incredible job playing a lonely and creepy man.  Unlike most of the pictures I've seen recently (Signs and Minority Report for example), the ending was not flat or anti-climactic.  I never once felt like a line was out of place or unimportant.  Everything made sense and there were no true surprises.  A well-written screenplay and many great performances made this a movie worth seeing over and over.

Say bye to Patch Adams!!!!  Thank goodness!!!  Robin Williams gives an Oscar worthy performance that is a polar opposite to his pre-2002, mawkish performances.  This tense thriller slowly builds to a surprising climax and provides several messages along the way.

This film could have been flawlessly great! One totally forgets that Sy Parrish is Robin Williams! Great Acting here!As Sy Parrish, Williams is totally believable, as he goes through a totally locked on (psycho) obsession with the Yorkins.There is a struggle; however, in the story that is strange? His reaction to what he finds out is totally off the wall. We don't know why he does the things he does? There is no reason for his strange behavior. Some brief flashbacks would have been the answer to this, not many--just a few, would have given this movie an added touch of fear and depth. The audience is left to decide this.I do; however, believe Robin Williams has found his best place in films, that of being the scary guy.I really hope you will do more worthwhile roles like this one!

Through his obsession with the perfect family  Seymour's experience tells us that there is no real functional family. All of them must have a dark side to keep on going,or working as has been agreed by society.Notwithstanding, there are little secrets that  only through a drastic inspection can discover the anomalies inside the photography.If you want to keep presenting the perfect portrait to society you must  manage to hide the blurry aspects of our lives. From this perspective the picture is clear.

You gotta love this movie for its strong drama. Williams is powerful in his role of a psychopath. Bizarre role for him... but he proved in the past to be as good of a comedian as a dramatist. In fact, the whole cast is well directed by Romanek.The movie is not meant to be fully packed with action, ridiculous bloody killings, meaningless story, super power special effects, explosions, etc.Anyone with a minimum of taste for a good drama thriller story will enjoy this movie. For anyone who is serious about rating a movie, it can't go below than 6/10. I can understand that some viewers didn't like this kind of movie... but it can't be 1/10. Come on! But I respect those idiots!

Review title: Williams in a roll that totally does him justice. A classic !!
Review_body: A fantastic original film leading the viewer wondering just how far will Williams the photo developer go. Is he sick and depraved evil man or is he just a lonely bachelor with a bad childhood and genuine admeration and love for the perfect family he has always desired. Wonderfully put together with a genuine plot and Williams's true acting capacity shines throughout.

If you were to read the plot ahead of time, you may not even look at this film as potentially good.  That's when you are reminded what makes a film good.  One Hour Photo was done flawlessly.It's the connotative combinations of the film's spaceless occasions that embrace its free place which amazingly chases, again, flawlessness.  One Hour Photo's haunting camerawork and lighting partnership allows the film to dig into the whole of your emotions.  It reminded me even more of the artfully appealing elements of Fight Club as well.  The audio works in such harmony with the film you don't even notice its independence, meaning you rather absorb the film as one "whole", disguising its elements through the genius of their intermixing fluidity.  Harmony, period, if you understand.Ultimately, how could you bear not to be captivated into the screen through which you watch this "soul", with the enlightment of Robin Williams, whom is often credited for single handedly successing the film with his brilliance. If perfection is not possible, he came as close to it as possible with his acting part as "Sey".  Short for "Seymore", pronounced as (s-eye), or the more common "Cy".  He directly defines a specific type of victim of mentality.  Too "on the dot" to even judge positively.  That's it, period.A psychoanalyst, such as myself, would find the movie interesting from a psychological viewpoint.  This defines "psychological thriller", as not only does it include chilling elements precisely caught through the the viewers realization of its characters mind state, but it also requires that psychologically aware mind from its viewer(s) in order be most effective. In other words, this is one of those films that actually requires a certain level of intelligence to even be understood.  These are the films which take films to new levels, that set new standards, that raise the level at which filmmakers must be at in order to achieve a certain level of credibility.Is there anything wrong with one-hour photo? Why did I give this film an 9 out of 10, not a 10?  It could easily be considered a 10, yes, a classic and a masterpiece, but that's where the entire concept comes in.  I think a 10 would require a foundation with even more substance, I almost gave this classic an 8 because it was a cameraman at Sav-Mart.  My view is simple, in order to achieve a 10, there could have been a more "interesting" concept to work with and from.  That's it.  The film is too close to perfect, it was manipulated perfectly from every aspect, brilliant, but a perfect 10 would have been made up of something more interesting. It's almost an 8 because not many will find a delicately smiling cameraman at the photo counter in Walgreens too captivating.  They will, however be caught and never let go of by everything you can do right and everything they never even knew you could do beautifully in a film.I would recommend this film in an instant to anyone who loves psychological thrillers, and I think next to anyone will be haunted by "Sey" the too nice guy's smiling eyebrows, not to mention their camera.  This is the end of snapshots.

Review title: praise for one hour photo, no spoilers
Review_body: OK, lets get down to it, one hour photo is one of the best films of the year, i say, with david fincher like direction, and unique lighting, it sends a message. Even better, it's a message to distinguish, it is a bit risky, with unique views into the mind of Seymore Parish, and think about that name, see more perish...with his job, i'm sure he does, i reccomend this movie for anyone with a conscience and any interest in humanity, and the many different perceptions people may have of it...and have fun deciding who the bad guy is.

Mark Romeck being a first time director, who's only previous experience was working on music videos, principley "nine inch nails." Many of the things that we are supposed to find frightening and disturbing are little riddles hidden in the movie that were supposed to figure out. This reminds me of Muholland Dr. in that respect, but not nearly as convuluted. Acting is allowed to slip when the scene is only supposed to serve a specific purpose. The ending is not very climatic. The problems with this film reduce it to being only watchable as a learning experiance in cinimetorgraphy and the setting of mood and emotion witch this movie ,however, did do well.

Review title: Surprisingly Effective and extremely good acting!
Review_body: One of this years great surprises was 'One Hour Photo'. A combination of beautiful acting by every single person to detail the disturbing story of a guy who processes photographic images for a family. You are told through the eyes of Sy, who takes extra caution in developing pictures for a family he has admired for years, the 'Yorkins'.A disturbing story that trancends into a moral plot within the final stages. The directing was very very impressive and the plot change was very good, but it did not seem dramatic enough to intitle it as a thriller. Everyone at first has a notion of a troubled guy who wants to harm the family but as it progresses you see a totally different side to 'Photo Guy' Sy.This movie is definitely worth a viewing, Robin Williams acting is incredible with the moral story within being an important lesson that we all usually, at some point in our lives take for granted.7/10

Review title: One Great Movie, Every Photo Lovers Should Peak
Review_body: This is a great movie, one of the best in the year, just look at the cast.. it's very good it really feels out the truth of the regular looser modern man, how it can be affected when it sees how a successful guy does bad things... this director really left his print on this movie... he uses the audience like the director of the sixth sense making of all the aspects a really passive suspense that can bring you to bite nails... and it's not that often we can enjoy a movie of this genre with robin williams as the bad guy (loser guy) if u haven't seen it... what the f*** are u waiting for???

Review title: If you hated this film, you have no taste or human feelings.
Review_body: Could someone please email me if you hated this film, but can give an intelligent reason as to why? I would like to debate this film with you, if you want. I do not understand how someone could be bored by such an amazing film. Riveting, original and sad. This film is about how people are mistreated in this society and what they do if unchecked or unloved. If some of you can't understand this, there is no use for someone to hold your hand. Try thinking about other people, that is what the movie says.Only hateful people would hate this movie. email me.I don't get why someone even bothers

Review title: An excellent movie that leaves you thinking
Review_body: I was drawn to one hour photo simply because i saw Robin Williams name under it in the TV guide. After watching this movie I was amazed at Williams performance and the sheer depth of this film. Sy Perish (played by Williams) is a lonely photo finisher who secretly takes a certain families photos and pretending that they are his family. This film is not particularly easy to watch but keeps you drawn to it until the end. Robin Williams was excellent in this role proving that he's not just a one trick pony and has very impressive acting skills that make the film all the more believable and enjoyable. As you watch his character throughout the film you don't know what to feel for him. Sad or Sick.

Although Robin Williams performance was worth watching, the storyline was ridiculous!!SPOILERS.... 1) Why did Williams' character develop the photos of his boss' kid, knowing that it would prompt an investigation?  Shortly thereafter, the cops are looking for him knowing he might be dangerous.  Why didn't he just go after the husband and his mistress without the threat to the boss?  I guess it was needed to make the story work to its ending.2) Williams' character has been keeping prints of this family for nine years, yet it's just determined after this amount of time has elapsed that the count on the photo machine is off?  You've got to be kidding!!!  Again, his firing was needed to make the story work to its ending.I'll post more when I have more time.....

Review title: Robin Williams gives an awe-inspiring performance,fantastic direction
Review_body: This film is definitely on my top 10 list for this year, maybe even all time. Robin Williams plays his character so subtley and controlled that it freaks the hell out of you yet demands sympathy from the viewer. You can't help but feel sorry for his character (Sy) and how he is so disconnected from the rest of the world. Also *possible spoiler ahead* his confession at the end with the police officer and the apartment scene were particularly chilling and disturbing. I also thought the musical score was excellent. I'm not entirely sure who wrote it but it suits the mood perfectly. Try to listen as the score swells up at the near end of the movie. That part just gave me goosebumps. This is by far Robin Williams' greatest performance EVER. This proves that Williams is not only a comic genius, but he can act as well. You totally forget that you are watching Williams on screen most of the time. In conclusion, do yourself a favour, and watch this film. I doubt it will do good at the box office but I really hope it gets nominations particularly the Oscars but you know how they are with comedians turning serious (Jim Carrey anyone?). But I warn you this film is not for the weak at heart nor mind. It grabs your mind and doesn't let go. It will leave you thinking long after you leave the movie theatre.

What can I say? I just loved this movie!! It may not appeal to the general public, but boy when I finished watching this all I could think about was what a great film this is and what an astonishing performance Robin Williams gave. He just gets better every day in my opinion. The directing and filming was also brilliant...it almost made me feel like I was the character himself! The music was perfectly fitting at all times too. A very well done movie, with superb acting and a mind-bender of a story. What more can you ask for?
Excellent choice for Mr. Williams. Everything works in this project on every level. Well acted. Well directed.

First off I was absolutely astonished by Robin Williams performance. In my opinion his best acting yet. The movie does an amazing job of pushing a feeling on you. In parts you just feel uncomfortable watching and creeped out, just wanted to yell, STOP BEING SO WEIRD. The shots the lighting the acting and the music add together to make you get this strong feeling, feeling exactly what the movie wants you to feel when it wants you to feel that way. That being an important part of a movie it does a perfect job, the movie also left me with a kinda "memento" aftermath feeling after I was done watching it. Leaving me to think about what I had just saw like the movie memento did, thuo probably less strong of a feeling. It gave me that puzzle piece falling together conclusion by the end you just thought about all the little details that all added up it was perfect, like a thousand threads making a perfect piece of cloth. It gave me the same aftermath feel as memento but didn't give me the constant headache memento did through out it, considering the movie was all backwards. For it being a relatively low budget film and a break out for the director it was a perfect piece of art, and should be enjoyed by allot more people.

This film seems to be not much more than a vehicle for Robin Williams to act up a storm, and that he does well.  The plot has so many holes in it I find it amazing that it got any good reviews.One example: "Sy" finds the pictures of the cheating husband, with his girlfriend.  These look like candid shots of the both of them frolicking, kissing (or rather, about to kiss), hugging, etc. Who took these candid shots?  Did they stop a stranger in the street? "Excuse me sir, could you take a picture of us just as we are about to kiss?"Another example, just for good measure: the police go to the hotel where they believe there might be some foul play taking place.  There are two rooms, Sy's room and the cheating couple's room.  The police first goes to Sy's room to find it empty and only then, to the other room.  Why do they not first go to the room where something awful might be happening?  or, better yet...  Why not send agents to *both* rooms, just in case?I could go on and on and on but, like the movie, it'd be to tedious.

I so wanted to love this movie. As a movie it's great, the supporting cast isn't stellar but Robin Williams' performance is nothing short of captivating. The movie begins well but seems to lose its footing in the middle, and by the end it made me too uncomfortable to be able to enjoy it properly. It's a good watch but is quite sad and some of the scenes towards the climax of the film are definitely up there for creepiness.

Yes, Robin Williams does steal the show.  He's an underrated actor, who, given a good script can deliver a mind boggling performance.  That's exactly what One hour photo is, a good script with brilliant performances.  The whole cast does an excellent job of showing how the events of one deranged man can impact the lives of many.  Let's get one thing straight, though, this not a mainstream movie.  It is very much an independant film.  If you don't like movies with little action or a low budget don't see this movie. This film is good because of its' strong performances and decent script. I must say, though, without Williams as the lead, this movie would not have been as good as it was.

Review title: Comparing One Hour Photo with Evangelion...
Review_body: "One Hour Photo" has something to deal with depression and some sexuality in it. However, this movie has one thing in relation to it, the animé "Neon Genesis Evangelion".So, you see Jake wanting a toy he wanted: a Mass-Produced EVA. Sy states to Jake that he's one of the "good guys", however, in the movie "End of Evangelion", they are really not.Sy, I'm guessing, is suffering from depression during this movie, and therefore is in some relation to Evangelion's Shinji Ikari (in which GAINAX's Hideaki Anno had suffered, therefore creating an animé with the main character with depression).Also in this movie, we see Sy resting and having a dream with endless shelves... eventually a scary sight with the eyes bleeding profusely. Then seconds later, the Mass-Produced EVA is standing on a nightstand. Think of "End of Evangelion", where Asuka Langley gets speared with the "Spear of Longinus" into her EVA's left eye, where she feels the pain. This spear, before transforming into Longinus (which the real one is on the Moon), was the weapon that the action figure has in hand, therefore the action figure is truly a bad guy, not a good guy.As Williams said in the commentary on the DVD, Evangelion is one of his most favorite animé... and the figure is one of his own from his personal collection.For being an EVA and Williams fan, this gets some serious attention and thought. 10/10 I give it.
A haunting performance from Robin Williams at his best.

This film will be remembered along with other great suspense movies of the all time. With this film, Mark Romanek should be considered easily on par with classic suspense directors like Alfred Hitchcock or Henri-Georges Clouzot."One Hour Photo" is an amazing character study with Robin Williams portraying a slightly disturbed, definitely quirky individual. There is no clichéd treatment to the film and this is what makes it timeless. The story unfolds deliberately and with a high sense of craft. There is an uneasiness felt throughout and it is obvious that the film makers want the viewer to experience this. They deserve accolades for not bowing to convention and potentially ruining what proved to be a clever finale.

The film keeps you watching by strongly implying that it will pay off. It invites the viewer to consider the emotional issues bothering the main characters as though they might matter later. What made this movie SUCK was it's superior attitude, demonstrated by it's refusal to give the viewer a climactic ending. Williams is always fun to watch, but he can't hold this one up. Anyone else in Cy's role would have immediately exposed this film as the stinker it is. He kept me watching 'til the lousy cop-out ending. If I didn't have a lovely girl with me the movie would have been a total waste of time.

My wife and I went to see this movie the other day for our anniversary, I can not express how greatly disappointed we both were, not to mention a majority of the other moviegoers. The film, in my wife's words,  we `just creepy, but not in a good way'. I could not wait for the movie to get over; I kept checking my watch to see when the movie was going to end. I have no idea what others saw in this movie to rate it so highly it I thought it was simply awful.

A little more work here and there in the direction and effects within this movie, and a little more drama or impact in the finale would have made this otherwise above average movie into an outstanding movie.  Still, it's one of the best performances by Robin Williams to date.  Slightly dark, good conveyances of emotion, good acting and directing make for a very enjoyable Friday evening movie.  The movie was particularly effective at portraying to the viewer the emotions and illusions within the emotionally unstable, or psychotic Williams.  You get your money's worth with this movie.

An alone old man (Robin Williams) develops an obsession for a young family, through  his job. Sy is a sad guy, without family and friends, who works with "picture revelations". A crime can be the beginning of end...One Hour Photo , techniclly, is a movie without errors, but there are some problems. All the story is centralized in just one action and the end is not very clear, but it is a very good(NOT GREAT) movie to see. Robin Williams is brilliant this time.

Review title: an intriguing premise, delivered very blandly
Review_body: the idea of this film intrigued me, a photo clerk who is obsessed with some of the people whos photos he develops.. robin williams plays the role of said clerk very well, his performance is the only redeeming quality of 1 hour photo. most of the dialog is very cliche, forced, and delivered so poorly by the rest of the cast/characters that it became laughable instead of serious. the script is horribly melodramatic. i disagree with anyone who says that this is a very untypical, un-hollywood movie because it does not dare to explore the main characters dark side at all. this really bothered me, this is what i went to the movie for and paid my money to see.. how disturbed can this normal looking store clerk be? well hes not too bad off (unfortunately). he keeps pictures of a family he doesnt really know and has fantasies about living with them.. whats the big deal? he never poses any danger to anyone when its all said and done. why do we need to explore this character for two hours?
This movie looks good. aesthetic. The photografy, the colors are great! I don't have much to say about the story (which I thought a bit boring) but I loved the end..

Review title: Williams shows us that he is one of the best in Hollywood.
Review_body: My favorite thing about this film was the fact that the lead character Seymour Parrish, played by Williams, was not as black and white (no pun intended) as many of these so called 'psychos' we see in these thrillers popping up all over the place.  We understood and are as the film rolls to a close made to understand what has driven this man and how, given his life, we may make the same choices he has made.  I found it very disturbing to find myself identifying with this man and yet feeling so very far from him. This falls heavily on excellent writing, but could not have been possible without the stellar performance of Oscar Award winning actor Robin Williams.This films release falls very close to the release of Robin Williams' latest stand-up comedy special on HBO.  It's amazing to see this man transform himself from the insane comic to this brilliantly played character.  It does nothing but reassure us, the audience, that Mr. Williams is not only one of the greatest actors of our time, but maybe one of the finest ever.  This is not to deny the well-played performances of the supporting cast.  The ever beautiful and sexy, Connie Nielsen portrays the ever-loving mother, who even in the face of tragedy will never do anything to break up her family. Also, at times it is hard to remember that young Dylan Smith is an actor and not a young boy thrust into this situation.  My applause goes out to the cast of this motion picture.However, a film cannot survive on it's cast alone.  My hat goes off to director Mark Romanek.  A fan of Romanek's work as a music video director (particularly his work with Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails) I was simply blown away by his full length picture debut.  I was very impressed with the use of the RGB.  Anyone who knows any thing about the production of photography knows that the colors are done in levels of Red Green and Blue. The way these three colors are schemed throughout the fill was utterly brilliant.  Camera use and cinematography also help capture the surreal and horrifying reality of this film.I was also very found off the soundtrack.  Its simplicity gave the film the perfect feel.  If you look at the track from start to finish, you'll realize that the entire score is one huge build from start to finish.  It really pushes you toward what's coming next, which is what the thriller is all about.Overall I give it a 9 out of 10.  And if you know me, nobody ever gets a 10.

Review title: BEST BORING FILM OF THE YEAR
Review_body: Perhaps Anthony Hopkins could have pulled this off as the main character if it was written better. Seems this movie was only about Robin Williams and his acting. I suspected during the film that he was the exective producer and had financed this film.His character was not believable because Williams unfortunately shone through. It is an unthrilling "thriller." And I suspect the "R" rating was purposely derived by a few stupid scenes and remarks.Also, I barely could stay awake. No action occured until "Sy" ran down the parking garage circular ramp near the end of the movie. Too bad that this low budget movie will profit at the movie-goers expense.

One Hour Photo is a haunting portrayal of a man who is desperate for a connection with others.  'Sy' Parrish is "the photo guy", a developer for the one-hour photo shop in SavMart, and is passionate about his job.His job presents him the opportunity to see the photos that people in his community bring in, and one family in particular has his keenest interest. The Yorkin family, a family of three with whom Sy feels connected with, as if they were his own.This movie is really brought alive by Robin's performance.  I definitely recommend seeing this if you get the opportunity.

Sorry, but I'm having trouble finding the meaning of this film. I went into the theater with no expectations. I read some of the reviews that described the movie as "deeply terrifying" and "creepy." I also noticed that Robin Williams was playing a "bad guy" in the film, and after seeing last summer's "Insomnia," I was ready to return to the dark side of Robin William's persona. Well, I must say that this movie was very dissapointing. It seemed to drag on and on...and I don't mean that this is a character-driven movie...it is just plain BORING. Nothing seems to happen. By the end of the film, I didn't really care what happened to the main characters (neither did half of the audience in the particular showing I saw, who got up and left before the movie was even over.) I felt no suspense, no terror, no edge-of-my-seat intensity. Hopefully this turkey will be forgotten in the following months. The only thing "deeply terrifying" about this movie is that it was actually made.

Review title: One of the most disturbing films in recent years.
Review_body: I went into this movie with very little prior knowledge of what it was really about. Robin Williams is excellent as Sy "The Photo Guy" as well is the rest of the cast. I remember seeing one review for this movie where the person said that the family in the movie wasn't focused on enough to have too much sympathy for them. I disagree; I think the family is focused on about as much as Sy himself. The overall feeling I got from this movie was extremely similar to the one I got after watching Requiem For A Dream. I really didn't know how to feel. I didn't know which characters to feel pity for and which to not. The reason for feeling this way was because the movie was extremely disturbing - I mean, just to think that someone like this could be out there. It doesn't have to be someone developing your photos. It could be a child's teacher or even a close friend. The reviewer who stated that this film would do for photos what Psycho did for showers was correct. And to tell you the truth, I think as a dramatic thriller, this movie stands up well next to Psycho.

Finally a great a show again. Williams is unbelievably good. Reflects on people's rage and alienation, somewhat similar - but delivers much more of a punch - to "Falling Down" and "Changing Lanes". Wish they made more movies like that.

One Hour Photo is a film of supreme caliber. The film is powered by the haunting, chilling, silencing, and above all-genius performance by Robin Williams. But the rather extraordinary thing is that it is not Robin Williams on the screen, it's Sy Parish (the character's name). Robin Williams fades away from our senses and slips into the ever so sweet and innocent yet psychotic role of a supermarket's photo developer. The films script is only accented by Williams, at times, restrained performance. Williams ignites on the screen and burns till the last frame, and you are unable to take your eyes off him. As I mentioned the film is subliminily written as well as directed. Though being Romanek's first, I certainly don't think this is a bad start. Romanek's direction adds to the on-going tension throughout the film. More affecting is Williams' delightful calmness. Trying to hold himself in becomes more troublesome for both Williams and his character as the story develops. Yet through the calm eyes of an innocent blaze the fires of hatred and intensity, which could very well sum up Williams' performance. The film does have some disturbing images as well. Yet they are not really strong enough for you to get up from your seat and leave yet rather the opposite. Williams' contribution as well as guidance towards the actions and scenes of peril compell as well as amaze you towards both the performance and film itself. Williams' shocking contribution to the screen is enough to make you cry, scream, and yell in your seat. Because the origins of the character are bittersweet just like own known Williams, leads to a crazed and psychotic breakdown. It's as if watching our own funny and beloved Robin fail us. Though the truth could not be any further, Williams but succeeds in the art of acting, creating an achievement in the field. Creating a landmark. Writing his/its own chapter. I guarantee that this film will be required study material in acting classes for now on. In conclusion: definitely one of the best of 2002.

Review title: Not typical Hollywood BS, but not that good either
Review_body: OHP is definitely a twist on the typical Hollywood crazy guy terrorizes people with guns psycho story, but is  still ultimately cliche, derivative and relies heavily on pop-psychology. "cleanliness/sterility=perfection...or does it?" Sums up the central theme of the film; nothing new here. The film has been compared to Taxi Driver and I definitely see that comparison, but OHP I felt was much tooderivative of and less compelling than psychological thrillers like Taxi Driver, Full Metal Jacket, et al. So, while OHP is a pleasant change of pace from the shoot 'em up mold, it's not particularly good either.

Review title: My breakfast cereal is scarier than this!
