Review_body: To me there was not a single moment in this film when I felt scared or frightened. Let's just cut to the chase and say "This movie blows. It blows hard." Who in their right mind said this thing was a scary experience?All I saw was a loser Wal-Mart employee who has a bit too much time on his hands. The movie also moves at a incredibly slow speed. Hell, I can knit faster.The actors gave a horrible performance, except for Will, but there was nothing he could do to save this horrible picture. Oh, wait that reminds me...he could have freakin' killed those two people! He didn't even cut them!If you can get by the slow start and the slow middle of the film you naturally expect a grand finale, but in this case you get a big handful of HORSE****.Honestly, I think I wasted a Free freakin' Coupon! God damn you "One hour photo"!

I don't know exactly why I chose to rent this movie out. I suppose I was initially drawn to it by Robin Williams. Nevertheless, I found myself with this movie for a week and viewed it that night. I still don't know why I chose it. Its never been recommended to me by anyone. I've never heard any praise of it. And I wish I had taken this lack of recommendation or appraisal as an indicator. I did not particularly enjoy this film. It looked clean, had some fine composition, and stylistically it had potential, but the characters were flat. They came off as two dimensional as the Ikea catalog they seemed to be taken from. I couldn't sympathize with the family, and it all seemed to be a glossy and neat style of cinematography trying to cover bad writing. Psychological thrillers come a lot better than this.

Rarely does a mainstream studio produce something with merit, so when it does happen it's worth mentioning.  And this is a film worth mentioning.Without doubt, Robin Williams is the highlight of this film.  His character is stirring, complete and believable.  Truly captivating.  Time and again he surprises with these brilliant performances that are difficult to fathom considering his humble beginning in sit-com TV and this is some of his very best work.Unfortunately, much of the rest that makes up the film doesn't rise to William's caliber and the end result is diminished because of it. Questionable story line (though a good concept and initial setup), weak supporting cast and non-existent (supporting) character development conspire against what would have otherwise been a 'Best Of' class film.Overall, definitely worth seeing, but without Robin Williams this would have been a B-movie relegated to the teen market and never mentioned again.

Robin Williams does a great job of shedding his funny guy persona here. His Sy Parrish gives me the creeps – from that moment Connie Nielson's Nina Yorkin walks into his One-Hour Photo shop. Williams provides more creeps here than he did in Insomnia. Just take a look at the light thinning crew-cut hair on this bespectacled middle-aged man with the stone-cold, mousy looking eyes and very disturbing smile. He reminds me of a weird and twisted mind with many faces. Just observe Parrish's behavior and it'd be hardly impossible not to be afraid of him. Oh yes, the viewer will get to know his character – slowly and gradually, feeling the tease; wondering what he'd do next. It's his deceiving appearance that truly petrifies an ordinary guy who seems so ordinary to some, yet turns out to be a low-keyed 'psychopath'. Yuks - that's exactly how I feel, studying him and his moves! The moments are very intense and scary. Look out for hints to Parrish's traumatic experiences because they help to connect the events and explain his fantasies and 'schizophrenic' wackiness. You truly have got to compare Michael Vartan's Will character to Gary Cole's Bill Owens. Maybe that too will help you accept the ending of the story.

Mark Romanek missed the chance of making a great movie. All elements to a good thriller were there, but Romanek seems to have lost inspiration half way to the end, or was he frightened by Robin William's character dimension? This is likely to be one those cases the creature threatens the creator thus forcing creator to cut its life short due to utter lack of handling a character with a life of its own. Needless to say Mr.Williams is able to conceive unthinkable countless different types, but in this first ground-breaking close to real psycho, he definitely stands on the edge of giving birth to an unlimited ever-disturbing classic social misfit ready to be displayed in the vast gallery of top psychos created by cinema along its history, by delivering a performance that outgrows Romanek's capacity to direct such complex performance. That's when he notices the character has to be let well enough alone; otherwise he is bound to demand much more from what the director had thought of.I was surely sold, up to the first half of the movie. I thought I was about to watch something that would over step the boundaries set by "Cape Fear", "Silence of the Lamb" or even "Taxi Driver", but I learned a lesson: A classic will be a classic, and pretentious efforts shall inevitably be condemned to oblivion!

I saw this movie both in theaters and on DVD, and I found it to be very entertaining both times. Not only does Robin Williams do a wonderful job at portraying the lovable, yet psychotic Sy Parrish, but he also makes the story so eerily believable that it is scary. The way in which Sy stalks the family throughout the film is downright disturbing, and something that you wouldn't expect from the cheerful clerk at the beginning of the film. All in all, I found this movie very interesting and I enjoyed it very much. Even when you find out what type of a sick freak Sy really is at the end of the film, you still feel sorry for him. I strongly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good thriller, or a movie in which Robin Williams strays from his comedic style. 10/10 for me

Review title: boring, linear plot with inadequate climax and unsatisfying "twist"
Review_body: I just watched this movie and simply wanted to comment on how boring and linear this narrative is. I don't know how many script edits this went through but it deserved a few more in my opinion. The so-called twist at the end of the film is unsatisfying as it fails to properly re-contextualise what has gone before; instead it merely throws in some back story that provides a deeper psychological motive for his actions. There is no gradual culmination of threat/suspense to engage the audience, rather the narrative progresses almost immediately from the inciting incident (protagonist loses his job) to his initial act of retribution (threatening photos of his bosses kid in the park) to his final act of "mania" in which he forces an errant father of a picture perfect American family to engage in a mildly degrading photo shoot (at knife-point) with his second, illegitimate lover. Then he is arrested and confesses to having been abused as a child. I felt this climax (the revenge photo shoot for the fathers infidelity, which we learn retrospectively to reflect his experiences as an abused child) should have been stronger. It wasn't dark or inventive enough to illicit any real emotional reaction - in me at least - and centres around the two characters who have been developed least (consequently, we care about them less). Nothing really culminates in this scene that has been adequately seeded earlier in the movie and fails to take one by surprise. We know he's gonna do something "dark" from the first act. When it finally happens it is over in minutes and fails to subvert any expectations the writer may have chosen to inculcate in his audience. Robin William's performance is alright - it ain't that demanding a role for the guy to be honest. I.e. it doesn't require anything from him as an actor that we haven't seen him do before. Over-all, its a bit of a plain Jane of a movie. zzzzzzzzzzz

Review title: was he abused as a child?
Review_body: At the end when the detective says "i think i understand now" ! Did he mean that he though Williams was abused as a child, it seems that way as he became so emotional when he spoke about the dad not treating his family right. But this was a great movie i recommend it it isn't quite up there with Hitchcock but its on its way. Better than insomnia in my mind. a very deep movie with a sterling performance by Williams. I heard nothing of its award wins but it defiantly should have had some, especially one for robin Williams. Although there is one thing still puzzling me. What do all the photographs at the end mean? "snapshots". who knows!?!? The direction is brilliant 8/10
Great movie! Wonderful acting! Very eerie with imagery. Really makes me feel bad for Sy. He is lonely but obsessive and just wants love.

Review title: Good thing I have a digital camera
Review_body: Not only is Robin Williams character creepily (not sure if that is a word or not) scary, but he completely looks the part. Williams is at his dramatic best in this film. No crazy comedic outbursts like usual. His character is almost always in control, but when he does go over the deep end it is in rage.

Review title: A stunning, sympathetic portrait of a damaged man and the forces that tend to make such men
Review_body:
No, "One Hour Photo" is not for the faint of heart. Nor is it a movie to see if all you want is the escapism the movies so often offer us. For those who want that, there are no shortage of other movies out there, and good ones in their own right.Robin Williams characterization of "Sy, the Photo Guy" is wonderful, one of his best, a chilling, humanizing and many-layered portrait of a deeply disturbed individual. What struck me most in watching the performance was the tug-of-war in my own mind about his questionable sanity and his motives. While it's extremely clear from the start that he suffers some significant psychopathology, the ending leaves one wondering (at least a little) about the method madness, and whether it is he that is sick, or human society in the 21st century. We've come quite far from the use of psychopathology as a plot driver since such movies as DePalma's "Dressed to Kill."I don't wish to include any spoilers here.  Suffice it to say that by the end I felt that where Seymour went wrong (aside from his obsession) was in having motives that in a sense were a little too good, too moralistic, too rigid... but for reasons that the film ultimately justifies, without excusing or judging. I could see virtually nothing in the writing that was gratuitous or unearned, even if the situations did become rather extreme. Each character remained believable, and even those one was set up to dislike, such as Sy's boss (Gary Cole) were neither presented as saints nor absolute demons, but merely as flawed human beings with motives and drives that sometimes contributed to the unfortunate chain of events that are the throughline of the movie.Rather than demonize Sy, the central character, those who made this work bring us into Sy's mind in a way that is quite certain to be deeply discomfiting to many, but with a compassion and honesty that is only rarely achieved these days (or at any time in the past) in the movies.The screenwriter-director, Mark Romanek, is a talent I hope will go on to greater public appreciation with time, but whether that happens or not, may his projects always find a green light somewhere. He has only directed one other feature film I'm aware of, STATIC, which seems nearly impossible to find on video. The rest of his work, as is so often the case with visually stunning directors, has been in music video, including videos for Madonna and Nine Inch Nails.If I could find fault with anything about the movie it would be in the marketing. Where Romanek and Williams make Sy appear as a deeply flawed (and deeply disturbed) human being, he is clearly presented utmost as a sympathetic character.  This is quite a feat in an era where paranoia is rampant, especially when it comes to "stalkers" and the mentally disturbed. Yet the marketing campaign seems to present the simplistic cliche of the creepy stalker, emphasizing only the monstrous aspects of his nature.
I've noted in reviews here and elsewhere a certain polarization of opinion surrounding this film. Perhaps some of those who disliked the film were drawn in by the promises made in posters and ads, and felt cheated (or confused) that this was not the one-dimensional suspense thriller that marketing tried to sell it as?

Review title: View this movie as if it were a piece of art...
Review_body: Of all the films I've seen at the theater this year, One Hour Photo has been one of the finest.  Its production has taken years, giving Mark Romanek plenty of time to tweak his magnum opus to a searing perfection.  There are little clues of foreshadowing, that you'll miss, if you don't pay close attention to the film.  Robin William's acting is so vivid and convincing that it's hard to believe he once portrayed the flamboyant Mrs. Doubtfire. And the excellent use of colors, lighting and editing to convey emotions, is almost identical to the masterful cinematography of American Beauty.I must admit I wasn't thrilled about seeing a movie about an obsessive stalker, but to enjoy and appreciate this film, one doesn't have to like its subject matter.  When my mother asked me if she would like it, I said, `View this movie as if it were a piece of art.'  If you like a painting, you're going to like how it looks and makes you feel.  If you judge One Hour Photo based upon its disturbing content, you haven't fully appreciated its utter brilliance.

Terrible movie, a major disappointment.  The least thrilling thriller I've seen in a long time; there is no suspense.  The last five minutes hold your interest, but not enough to forget the first hour and a half.  It seems the director, writer and actors forgot one cardinal rule: the audience has to care about someone in order for us to remain interested.  There is nothing worth caring about.  Oh, and it's slower than slugs.

Review title: This film wasted nearly 2 hours of my life.
Review_body: A beautifully filmed student project given too big a budget for the predictable story of a milk toast psycho. We wouldn't watch it if the preview hadn't told us that -- once again -- Robin Williams is playing against type.  The film indulges in endlessly tedious small talk and purports to scare consumers who are really more affected by their own transgressions than the guy behind the film counter.  What next -- scary mailman?  Psycho gardener, zealous gas station attendant?  The best part was the very end, after the film was over and we got to leave.  Unfortunately I left almost 2 hours of my life behind.

...starring Robin Williams.  A very excellent performance by a great actor, his limits show no boundaries.  He pretty much made the movie, the other actors were good, but some showed definite acting weaknesses.  It was an independent film, so it was definitely different than your run-of-the-mill main stream pictures.  I could see how some critics could say the movie is "slow", I consider it character/scene development.  You have to be prepared for this type of pace, if so you will definitely come out enjoying it.

I watched it on a flight yesterday.  I watched the whole thing since the screen was right in front of me, and I couldn't imagine that Robin Williams would have been in a movie that was that bad.  If I had been in a theatre I would have walked out.

I'll try to avoid divulging anything actually in the plot and touch on the overriding themes.  Yes, it is conspicuously disturbing and probably should be filed under the same classification that contains Full Metal Jacket and A Clockwork Orange and consequently is rightly rated R.  That said, for the right audience, it delves into the quandary oft pondered, Where does categorical love cease and morph into destructive psychological illness?  Furthermore, focus on the plight of the lonely white lower-middle class worker who feels that society (read special interests and the government) neglects him but chooses to forgo complaining. Probably the the most potent element to the film is that it is quite realistic.  The acting, script, and plot stand muster.  9/10.

Review title: Does for photos what Jaws did for water
Review_body: This movie was stunning. I will never look at photos the same way again. Robin Williams gives a performance of such nuance, it will go down in history as one of best performances of all time. The whole movie I didn't know whether he should get caught, or he should get away with everything. I recently saw Insomnia and thought it was the best Williams I had every seen or ever will see. I was very very wrong. I don't suspect the film will win Best Picture, because the Academy doesn't go for films like this. However, it better win Best Actor, or I will loose all respect for the Oscars. 10/10

Review title: One Hour Photo delivers in the end.
Review_body: One Hour Photo is a thriller of a different sort. While the buzz is about Robin Williams taking on a dark, malevolant role, the substance is a unexpectedly honest look into the mind of a stalker who perceives himself as anything but.Mark Romanek puts the audience through a variety of paces, forcing us to re-evaluate our opinion about Seymour (Sy) Parrish throughout. Williams performance transcends himself, and allows the viewer to forget who the actor is and focus on the story within the first 1/2 hour. He is uncharacteristically subdued, and often leaves you wishing for more animation and insight, though this is obviously deliberate, and ultimately a boon to the film.The story develops around Sy's peripheral involvement in Nina (Connie Nielsen) and Will (Michael Vartan) Yorkin's and their son's life, via years of developing their family photos. Sy quietly adopts the Yorkin's as his own family, but what starts as a benign fixation is slowly revealed as much more, in remarkably subtle, but twisted examples. While we are immediately told that Sy has done something wrong at the beginning of the film, Romanek leads us on a red-herring filled chase to the end.Nielsen gives a realistic portrayal of an unhappy housewife in a financially successful marriage, though Vartan comes off paper thin throughout, particularly in a rather stilted marital tiff designed to clue us in on the state of the Yorkin's life. The son, uncredited here, provides the biggest dramatic peril, as he immediately connects with the viewer, but ultimately his competition for screentime with his mother blunts the emotional impact intended.Romanek's unique approach to staging, color choice, and costuming all lend to a surreal view into his characters everyday life. While his approach to symbolism can be heavy handed at times, at others it is equally subtle, and effective in either case.Despite these shortcomings, One Hour Photo delivers in the end, leading to a stunning climax uncommon in today's Hollywood fare. One Hour Photo is a leap into a new approach in audience manipulation, character insight, and selective plot development. A strong effort, that may come up lacking in box office success, but will certainly find its audience in video sales, and overseas distribution.

I'm writing this review 16 years after the film was released, however the message that the film conveys is still very relevant today. Personal cameras using film and dropping the film somewhere to be developed, had largely been abandoned for camera phones, and other digital devices. The late Robin Williams plays Seymour "Sy" Parrish, a lonely but friendly photo counter clerk at a Walmart type big box store. He slowly becomes obsessed with a young, seemingly "picture perfect" family whose personal family photos he develops. One day Sy runs into the husband, Will, who's shopping at the savmart, and Sy approaches him with the awe and excitement one may have, had they met their favorite celebrity in public. This display showcases the obsession Sy has with this family, and is almost disturbing in nature.The message conveyed is of the grass is always greener....or things and other people who look good on paper, or in this case, film...isn't always the case. Today in the age of Facebook and other social media, we're all vouyers in a sense, peeping in on other's lives, that appear carefree, fun, exciting and flawless. Robin Williams voice narration summed up this trend perfectly, that NO ONE photographs or records the mundane or painful parts of their life, we the onlookers only see the good. Ironically, it is a very painful and negative situation taking place when someone takes what may have been one of the few photos ever taken of Sy...his jailhouse mugshots.My only nitpicks are a couple of scenes in the movie that never would happened in real life. One is when Sy is watching the little boy Jake's soccer practice. The coach probably saw this strange man lurking around the playground, yet still allows Jake to wander off with him after practice. Even though Jake reassured his coach that Sy was harmless, I still don't see that happening ever. The other nitpick, is that Nina Yorkin appeared somewhat uneasy with Sy's over friendly, somewhat creepy nature when she ran into him at the mall (he was actually following her around), and his over enthusiasm over her family photos....yet she continued to use his photo counter even though there were probably thousands of other film developing places in town.Overall, a great character study of a slowly unraveling man.

Cinéphiles will probably like this film much. Semiology lovers will be delighted by this slow pace, "framed" movie that could have been only a "style exercise"... For those who like comparisons, let say that Kubrick (Shining) & Antonioni (The Eclipse,Blow-up)for instance, could be somewhere in the director's mind... More can be added... Romanek signed here a very different american film, the kind I like most; intelligent, thoughtful, without all the usual childish plot and directing. Use of the depth of field and frame fit well within the subject. Robin Williams is just so accurate. Not much words but the good ones, his eyes just tell us the whole thing... Check this film.... People will talk about soon...

Okay, I've seen tons of films in my years and none have been as bad as this.Unsuspensful, unentertaining and just plain stupid.  The film has what could have been an excellent premise for a film, but fails to deliver any sort of drama or suspense.  Robin Williams plays a delightful character who cracks after having what he would consider a horrible day.  True to life, the character does what he think is justice without any "violence", which while this may be a great tribute to the common man reaction.  It does not make for an entertaining film.Skip it and wait for rental if you feel you really must see it.

When I saw the trailer I was a little reluctant to go and see it because it definitely seemed promising but also too scary :). But finally I so wished to experience a potentially good film that I went risking the following nightmares. I will not have any. I made a mistake but for an entirely different reason. The film was so empty and boring that it simply shouldn't have been spent money on (not only my buying a ticket but on producing it). It is only the performance from Robin Williams (Sy, the photo guy) that gave something to watch, as a study in acting, perhaps, but the script is so shallow and hollow that it hurts. What bothers me most is that this film has a certain so-called "arty" approach, overly simple script, pretentious direction and photography among others. It strives to be subtle and but it is affected, has no strength and no depth. I have seen enough good and bad European films to recognize it immediately. There is the classic approach: "show and don't tell" which has been clearly not heard by Romanek or simply overlooked. He should try much harder or not at all.

I really did not like Robin Williams and there wasn't any movie that could have changed my mind. Until this one. As in this movie Robin Williams perfectly transforms into a man who is visibly VERY LONELY. Lonely the way a man just can be on planet Earth. Yes, the whole movie was built on his loneliness I know. But it is amazing to watch someone, an actor to act perfectly like the loneliest human being in the world. Because he moves he talks he cries he walks he turns the way that one can instantly recognize someone in his neighborhood. The loneliest one. And it was so heartbreaking that I could hardly bear it. I grew up in a big, loving family, in a family he is only yearning for. And I can not help him and any other people like him. How sad. One Hour Photo is one of the most depressing movies I have ever seen.

This movie is, essentially, bland.  That's pretty much it. We hated it. There was no variety in pace, the whole movie was just slow.  Well, it went a bit faster at the end, but it was still slow.  Just think: first hour - slug, last half hour - snail.  Not only is it slow, it is beige.  Very, very beige.  Yes, we do know that there is a point to that, but it is a very obvious point.  In the first three minutes, you'll get all the symbolism, and then spend the rest of this movie waiting for some colour.  The director/ writer has to realize that basing an entire movie around a boring character will likely lead to a boring movie.  Only see it if you have a strong affinity for beige, wear adult running shoes with velcro, or go to baskin robbins and order vanilla ice cream.  Not french vanilla, just vanilla.  If this applies to you... go out and see this movie.  I feel very sorry for you.  If not, there is only one part of the movie you'll enjoy - the blood eyes.  If you're willing to pay $15 to see what I'm talking about... fine.  But trust me, IT IS THE ONLY GOOD PART.

One Hour Photo is a remarkable film to watch. Strong cinematic cues underpinthe story. Monotone, washed out colours surround Sy Parrish, a regular onehour photo guy, seems to live a deprived life. No friends, no family. Only the colourful countless faces and moments of his customers as he processes theirfilms.One young suburban family becomes the target of his obsession and we followSy as he descends into the potential of his character.Robin Williams is brilliant and his performance is a true reflection of his genius as an actor. The cinematography is beautiful - director Mark Romanek's musicvideo experience shows clearly, and effectively.Upon reflection, One Hour Photo starts off with a great idea (the openingnarrative of Williams' character reveals brilliant observations about snapshots), but the film unravels rather disappointingly. But see for yourself - it's worth the try.

Review title: Excellent! Academy Award for Robin Williams!
Review_body: If you don´t like Robin Williams, forget it. Go and see this film. He(or what we associate with "Robin Williams") disappears into the role of a sad and lonely "Nobody" and I think, this is Robin Williams at his best movie since years. You may be surprised to see him in such a dark film (it´s a very sad movie), but if you look more carefully at some other characters he played, you also will find lonely, isoated people who have one deep longing for : to give love and to receive love. Now we see a stalker, a voyeur who makes desperate efforts to get a little bit love and it ends with violence. Pefect performance, book and camera!

Forget your expectations. Robin is absolutely terrifying as the sad, damaged photo clerk trapped in retail psycho-hell. Calm and mild-mannered on the outside, he's a ticking time-bomb ready to explode. Gary Cole as his evil boss is a stroke of pure genius. (Think 'OFFICE SPACE'. Think Lumberg's angry brother.) This film is dark, haunting, and brutal - finally a worthy return to the harsh, lonely-man films of the 70's. I've heard the original workprint was better; more subtle and less-coddling (before the FOX execs butchered it) but this is still one effective and astonishing film you won't soon forget. Written and directed by the guy who did the "Closer" video for Nine Inch Nails -- 'nuff said.

Review title: Psychological/intellectual thriller: not for the impulse driven mind
Review_body:
____________________________________________________________________________ ____________________________________________________________________I read up on this movie at this site yesterday, but went to see it today. NOW I understand why some viewers were disappointed. I DEFINITELY WAS NOT!!! THIS WAS AN OUTSTANDING MOVIE!! The telescoping symbols in OHP tell a consistent, subtextual story that has the viewer 'put the pieces together.'  The writer/director, I believe intentionally eliminated outright, 'right-foot,left-foot' lame tell all storytelling, but allowed the viewer to assemble the information cumulatively.  This is a rare intelligent psychological thriller--like The Talented Mr. Rippley--only not so dark.Telescoping examples:   RW character is exemplified in the shot of the pet hamster, running as fast as he could in the exercise wheel.  Hamster lived within the given confines, and responded  with reflexive normalcy.
Meaning:  Sy is a person living the caged and kept 'hamster's life'.  He waits for the caretaker to feed him (Sy feeds hamster/Savmore feeds Sy).
The cage is Sy's knowlege and practice of confining animal expression wanting to get out, but not knowing how.The wheel is a telescoping metaphore for daily activities of life; whether the hamster goes fast, or slow, he does not go anywhere or exceed the boundaries of the cage.The 'eye' is a symbol for ultimately individual perceptual subjectivity in life.  Life is as we see it is.Some examples: photography as life sustaining, medical corneal lecture at hotel, the blood from Sy's eye in his mind, the argument in the store (3+ blue miscalibration)Meaning: a telescoping hint that Sy is highly influenced by the [eye's] information. He built his life around flat visuals--the pictures--and 'all was well' perception.  The perception was again put forward when after being fired, Sy turns up a photo on the floor and it is blank.  This is as far as the director went in [obviously] putting out the key his symbols for examination.I study movies for symbolic content--and HIGHLY RECOMMEND this one.  Robin Williams is an outstanding actor--and proved it here.  Anyone else "do metaphors"??

Well, this movie arrived to Monterrey,Mexico on September 9th. When i knew about this movie i was really excited! You know? Robin Williams! So i didn't hesitate and went to my favorite movie theater..... When the movie was finished i thought??... ITS NOT SCARY!!!, then i feel the movie was going so slow... it dosen't have any UP & DOWNS! The only good thing about the movie was the ACTING! I will recommend you to go and see it because only you (movie fans) can have the best opinion!

Man, what a let down. First I was bored to death with the first half of this movie. I only paid attention with hopes of a really disturbing ending. To be nice Williams played a good psycho and some of the camera work was interesting. But this movie gave me "cinematic blueballs". It just didn't live up to the build up. I would recommend this movie to all my enemies. If you wanna do a case study on anti-climatic endings than One Hour Photo is all you need. Save your time and money for something else- anything else!

This is not a movie that everyone will enjoy, but I think most people will like it if they don't have the wrong expectations.  This is not an ACTION film!!!!  There is very little 'action' in the literal sense and you should not go into the theatre expecting it, or you will be disappointed.  Many people complain that the film doesn't have as much action or violence as they expected, when the problem was that they were expecting any at all.  I would even go so far as to object to the 'thriller' label... much of the movie is not 'thrilling' but rather suspenseful and sad.There are 3 emotions on prominent display here, and Williams portrays them both very well: loneliness, sadness and anger. Throughout the course of the movie we watch Sy progress through these three states, and it is such a natural progression that it alone is what makes the film stand out.  Williams does an EXCEPTIONAL job in this role, which is fortunate because he gets most of the screen time.  People who didn't like his performance I think misread the role.  He does not (nor is he supposed to) have a crazy serial killer personality.  He is a repressed man - that is the reason for his sometimes stifled actions and emotions. I could picture myself in his shoes easily, and I didn't find myself yelling 'No don't do that you idiot!' at the screen as I am often known to do.  Audience members are able to closely identify with his emotions and that is what creates the suspense - because you know what you might think of doing if you were him - and these possibilities are unpleasant.  When you see Sy begin to act these things out it is really uncomfortable.A few more brief things I should mention..  the ending is NOT anti-climatic, when you consider the rest of the film and the character. The photography is quite good (no pun intended), and the music fits very well (sorry, didn't see the similarity to American Beauty...).  As long as you dont have a short attention span and are not expecting the wrong things I think you will greatly enjoy this film.   I give it a strong recommendation.  Grade: A

This was the most horrible movie I have ever seen. I would never ever see it again. And as far as that goes..I probably won't ever see a movie with Robin Williams in it again. He is absolutely horrible in these "serious" movies. I wasted my money on this joke. I should have walked out the minute it started because the whole time I was trying not to fall asleep. I also went with 2 other people and they hated it as much as I did...overall this movie sucked and whoever made this movie should be embarressed.

This is not the movie advertised.  This wasn't creepy or scary or anything other than mildly disturbing.  I've met more disturbed folks in daily life, and I don't work in an ER or police station.  I think there were several people in the theater more disturbed than Sy Parrish (RW's character). Although Robin Williams does give an adequate performance, that's the only worthwhile aspect to this film.  If you're interested in vehicles that showcase a performer's efforts, perhaps you'll enjoy this film.  Don't go for the story.  It's boring.  Another victim of hype....

Review title: Good movie but not a great movie.
Review_body: I did enjoy this movie but really felt there could have been a little bit more. Robin Williams did a great acting job and convinced me that there ARE hundreds of people like this running photo processing shops. However, be warned that if you dislike Robin Williams this movie will not alter your opinion. Overall though it is well worth seeing and will make you think twice about going to the same photo processing store! Try varying them a little!

Review title: Great movie! The story and Robin Williams are incredible. (Voted a 9)
Review_body: I have heard the reviews, and most of the ones I have heard have been horrible.  Many people say ... don't go see this movie, because it doesn't go anywhere, and doesn't say anything important.  To these comments, I respond with ... are you kidding? I thought this movie was incredible.  The way it was filmed, Robin Williams' character, and the story line are all intensely interwoven. I can understand why people say it doesn't go anywhere, or discover anything, because the end of the movie isn't blatantly stated, but if you pay attention, you'll leave the movie knowing a lot more about it than other people do.  Definitely see this movie, and pay attention.   Robin Williams delivers a stunning performance.

This movie will eat away at you. You get wrapped up in the story. Great performances all around. Robin Williams gives a heart felt performance. It will make you think twice. Very disturbing ride through one man's obsession.

Every couple of months I take my staff out for "movie night" on the boss. We had originally planned on seeing Fear Dot Com, but after the horrible reviews decided at the last minute to see One Hour Photo.  It was long, boring, and had NO substance.  Of the six of us that saw the movie, one person thought it was "OK", the rest of us couldn't believe how badly it STANK (and these were people that got to see it for free!)  There was no suspense, no horror, & no drama.  Just Robin Williams with bleached blond hair and a very weak plot.  I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone (in the theater or on video) unless you want to waste an hour and a half of your life that you'll never get back!

I like many types of movies.  What i paid good money for last night was awful.  The actors did a fine job, that's not my beef.  if this movie was an "emotional rollercoaster" then it was one without twists, turns, flips or even a slight turn.  the only thing this movie offered this movie-goer besides a display of acting was an unexpected ending, not a shocking one, just unexpected.  it leaves this movie-goer saying, "okay, whatever".

The film was put together OK, but it really was too slow.  So much more could have been put in here.  Robin Williams could have been stranger, or been strange in a more interesting way.  I really don't understand how the film has been rated so highly.

This is an overrated, highly predictable and heavy handed, boring picture. Yes Williams gives a good performance, but the plot and directing are mediocre at best.  There is virtually a neon sign flashing "Foreshadowing" across the screen at every turn.

One Hour Photo is the best movie I have ever seen. There's no way to describe it--the only thing I can say is that it is the story I've been trying to write for the past two years...maybe not in storyline, but in general feel, photography, and dark, yet whimsically sarcastic and unknowingly-insane narration.The way that Sy narrates, in a way that he thinks he is normal and stable, is amazing--I love films that play on that (like A Clockwork Orange and Flowers for Algernon, although the latter is an innocent form of mental instability)But the way that Mark Romanek portrays the fine line between good and evil is what really makes the movie sing. Although Sy is the good guy in it all, he still holds an immensely creepy and Norman Bates-esque air about him and his actions. The concept of voyeurism and how far it can go is contrasted perfectly with the juxtaposed notion of being the protagonistic hero who does the right thing--but which one has a greater weight in the scheme of morality?god bless movies that have double meanings!And the photography is simply stunning in approach, as well--such as the slightly off centering of some scenes and the subtle yet noticeable change in camera color filters which correspond to the colors used in the color photography process.just see it, that's all...just go and rent it, buy it, whatever.

I loved this movie! Just loved it. If you think the Robin Williams is a great comedian - wait till you see this... if he keeps this way he will certainly win an Oscar.This movie really makes you think, and you will keep on thinking long after you return the DVD back to the store.

Review title: A film worthy to be mentioned with Hitchcock's greatest
Review_body:
This is a film Hitchcock would have been proud to call his own.
One user commented that this film was "so-so" due to the fact that the Yorkins weren't given much depth.  Well, this film isn't about the Yorkins. It's how one troubled man sees the Yorkins and how he sees himself with them.The scariest part about this movie, is that we all know someone like Sy. We've met someone at the photo lab or laundromat like Sy.  Hitchcock took ordinary people and the circumstances they live in and made them suspenseful.  Mark Romanek has done the same and met the bar Hitchcock set.Williams deserves an Oscar for this film, but we already know he won't get it.  The powers that be and their politics have already determined that Williams has won his one Oscar and that's all he's entilted to because "he's not really an actor."   Romanek at least deserved a screenplay nomination, but damn it, all the man has done is music videos so there is no way in hell we'd give him a nod on his first try.Kudos to Jeff Cronenweth.  His cinematography was beautiful, but alas, he won't get the nod for the same reasons as Romanek.As a side note, Romanek obviously spent some time in a Wal-Mart, or knew someone who did.  As a former employee (God help me) I could only laugh during the break scenes at work and those wonderful SavMart smocks.

This movie is definately one of a kind.  I have never seen Robin Williams play anything besides a giddy babysitter or or a loving father figure. Disturbing and intense, this movie keeps you creeped out and wondering who you're taking your film to, as Williams stalks the innocent suburban family. Great for an older audience (teens etc...), but I don't recommend it as a Friday night movie with youngsters.  There is brief nudity, but nothing serious.  Two thumbs up!

With all the good reviews I had seen (and the great score on imdb) I was really looking forward to this film.But what I actually got was an unbelievably weak plot where nothing rang true.  For example, the photos of a couple having an extra-marital affair - you've got to wonder who was taking these photos.  The strop the wife throws near the beginning at her husband also felt like it came from out of nowhere and seemed crass, at best.Robin Williams was fine in the lead role, but other than that I can't think of anything else positive to say about this film.  It never for a second became intriguing or even believable.  For a TV movie with average reviews this would have been fine.I'll give it 4/10, but that's based on Robin Williams' performance and the fact that I managed to remain awake throughout.

I still can't figure out what the point was.  The acting was phenomenal, the cinematography astounding, but the plot (or lack thereof) extremely disappointing.  If you're looking for a suspense-drama sans conclusion, this is it.  For those of us who like to know the ending of a movie, look elsewhere.
Boring and dull. Nothing to see here except brilliant Robin Williams performance.

I had an inkling that Robin Williams could do this sort of thing, but how well he did it! This is the movie that, for the rest of my life, I will never be able to watch again. Growing up with Robin (I was 7 or 8 when Mork & Mindy first aired), I knew the funny, tender, pleasant, hysterically hilarious sides of one of my Hollywood faves quite well. I was completely unprepared for the darker side of him. It blindsided me, yet held me captive, until the terrifying conclusion.On a technical note, the director chose to use a weird kind of filter that, combined with Robin's blond "do" for this film, created an eerie tone to the film that wouldn't have been present with out it.

Review title: Excellent directing, VERY promising talent in Romanek.
Review_body: This film is a beauty, a very good piece of directing that will definitely be among my top films of 2000-2010. Romanek shows a CLEAR mastery of the visual form, stark colours, powerful acting and a screenplay that should have gotten more acclaim. The film follows Sy (Robin Williams). A lonely photo-processing-attendant, with no life outside the four walls of the supermarket in which he conforms to a drab existence involving grey uniforms, tedious elevator music... an atmosphere only made interesting by cheating couples amateur porn. His only other shred of a life is collecting photos of a customer, which he pins on a wall to his apartment. Sy becomes enraged when a detail to the customers life is discovered and he sets about fixing the problem in his own Sy the Psycho way. But be warned, the film is sometimes (once) terrifyingly scary and also (again once) terribly shocking. However with such a strong story and a great director behind it, this film explores emotions that not a lot of others films have managed.Inspired visually, ideologically and thematically by the master that was and forever will be Kubrick, any fan of the films he made will not be disappointed. So to SK fans out there, watch it, see if you recognise his style in this. WARNING: Opinion may be biased.
